newsitem.title: USA: Wildfire threatens Athabaskan villages in Alaska.
newsitem.headline: Wildfire threatens Athabaskan villages in Alaska.

text.p: Firefighters were working Monday to contain a fast-growing Alaskan wildfire that was advancing toward three Athabaskan Indian villages, officials said.

The 158,000-acre Inowak fire consumed another 50,000 acres over the past two days and was about five miles north of the Kuskokwim River villages of Sleetmute, said Don Pitcher, a spokesman for the Alaska Division of Forestry.
The fire was also approaching two nearby villages, he said.
"The villages of Sleetmute, Red Devil and Stony River are all potentially threatened if the fires move through," Pitcher said.
A specialised firefighting crew was working in the area to protect buildings from burning embers, officials said, and other crews were cutting fire lines to protect the communities.
Sleetmute has about 120 residents, some 60 people live in Red Devil and about 40 in Stony River.
In all, 77 wildfires were burning around the state Monday, and firefighters were deployed on 16 of them, said the Alaska Fire Information Centre, a joint federal-state operation.

Other major fires included a 1,280-acre blaze northeast of Fairbanks, an 18,000-acre blaze that threatened a commercial lodge on southwestern Alaska's Tikchik Lake and a 248,000-acre blaze in the Innoko National Wildlife Refuge in Interior Alaska.
So far this summer, 530 fires have burned 721,000 acres statewide, said the Fire Information Centre.
The centre is part of the Alaska Interagency Coordination Centre, which coordinates U.S. Bureau of Land Management and Alaska Division of Forestry wildfire management.
